content.description:
A weird name, maybe in reference to Ha Ling which was once known as "Chinaman's peak" (thankfully changed for the better, as this was definately not acceptable).  
  
 Long and crimpy, this will test you with hard draws. A good sting in the tail too. Clean on TR

9 bolts to anchor

Starts at the right side of the wall sharing the first bolt (not necessary) with Bubble Theory.  Traverse right past two bolts, then up exposed face just to the left of the more overhung sections of the wall.  Some of the best pictures in the Bow Valley can be taken of this climb!

Right side of White Imperialist just before the more overhung section of the wall.
7 bolts and anchors

A direct start to A Bold New Plan. Stick Clip the first bolt and then get the 12a crux over with right away with bad holds and desperate moves to meet the much better original route at the second bolt.

Right side of White Imperialist Wall, Starts just at the rise into the very overhanging section of the wall on the right.
7 Bolts plus anchors

Similar to Rhymes with Orange, but shorter and not quite as fun.

Shares start with Bold New Plan past many small overlaps through first two bolts, then face. Last route to the right before obvious Bold New Plan wall and overhanging right side
4 bolts plus anchors

Before arriving at white imperialist proper, there is a huge tree that hides this GREAT line. Get on it. Hard start so stick clip!

7 bolts to anchor

Another reference to Ha Ling in the background?  
  
 Start on top of a boulder and climb left. Clean on  TR.

7 bolts to anchors

Start on Chinatown Left but then move towards the right (as the name states). Clean on TR.

8 bolts to anchor

Probably the steepest 12a in Grassi, if not all of the Bow Valley.  Start on blocky moves from the top of rock at the far right of White Imperialist Wall.  Move up and right to a strange almost slabby 5 ft section where any number of body smears can give you an OK rest.  Then make huge moves up pocketed roof to desperation turning the lip (go deep in the pockets). Amazing and very satisfying.

Farthest right route on White Imperialist wall, just right of large deep cave.  Lower off onto trailside climbs (Real Good Time)
9 draws (usually there are draws hanging on the route, but most have not been changed in 10+ years). Anchors

Another White Imperialist Face climb. Edges and increasingly slippery feet.

Just right of previous route.  Goes up right side of large ledge halfway up wall shared with previous two routes.
6 bolts plus anchors.

Easiest and very popular route on White Imperialist wall.  Goes up blocks, cracks, pockets and whatever else seems good and not to slippery. After second bolt go straight up (not right) to next two bolts and anchors.

Blocky disjointed section in the middle of wall (wherever the line of new climbers is).
4 bolts plus anchors

Slightly longer and the easiest of the White Imperialist  left side climbs.  Goes through larger pods at 1/3 height and then to the left of large blocky ledge which is mid-height on next two routes.  Finishes just before large slanting ledge 60ft up.

Middle of White Imperialist left wall (4th route from left).  Look for larger pods 15ft up.
7 bolts to anchors

Shares first two bolts with Gizmo, then traverses right across easy terrain to join Johnny Mnemonic for last three bolts and anchors.  If you are using a bad hold, you are doing it wrong.

Really just an easy linkup of two adjoining routes, but...
5 bolts plus anchors

Good fun climbing up blocky edges and pockets. Pretty direct with crux in first half and then easy .7 second half.

Last route left before slight downhill at the base of wall leading to slight overhanging start of following routes. Just right of 15ft tall right facing corner.
7 bolts plus anchors

Short right facing corner continues on big holds. Watch for the sting in the tail

6 bolts to anchor

Easier face climbing on smallish edges and pockets to a steeper, more blocky section. Going right around the crux at the second last bolt makes it 10c, going direct is 11-.

Leftmost route on main section of White Imperialist (there are two others up and to the left)
8 bolts plus anchors

Another good face climb. crux up higher.

Up the middle of the large blocky ledge in the middle of this section of the wall.  Directly across from petroglyph rock.
5 bolts plus anchors

Really fun climbing on pockets that seem much steeper than it is.

Stars off stack of blocks at the base of the beginning of the overhanging right side of wall.
5 bolts plus anchors

Crux is around the second bolt, where there is a very tough bouldering move to get over a ledge. After this the climbing subdues quite a bit.



Starts just to the right of the big tree at the far left of White Imperialist wall, on the upper left tier. Approach by hiking around the side from the left end of White Imperialist.


6 bolts to a bolted anchor.

Slick and thin, but fun movement.  
  
 Second route from the left on main wall. Starts on slab with small, sharp pockets.

6 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor

slick.  Just right of White Imperialist at the furthest protrusion of the White Imperialist Left wall. Ends just before upper ramp.

7 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor

Although this crag is named "White Imperialist," it has never been the desire of the First Ascension and the Developers to name this crag in a way that was demeaning or incited racial prejudice to the different people (predominately Asian in this case) that are target of these different route names.

The background to these names are that there is a nearby mountain (seen from the crag) named Ha Ling that was until recently referred to as "Chinaman's Peak." These names were in a way a critique on how this was seen as politically correct at the time even though using a very unfortunate and derogatory term for an Asian-Canadian. Since the re-naming of Ha Ling was completed 1997, this is now the time to change this critique of western imperialism as well. Currently, many parties are working with the First Ascentionists and developers to find better names as this critique is now lost and many see these names standing to continue the same racial prejudice that the developers wanted to critique.

The FA and other parties are currently reviewing these route names in hopes to eliminate any issues going forward.
